sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Defense officials from over 40 countries attend NATO talks in Germany assessing Ukraine's calls for more military assistance. The U.S. pledges allies will keep moving heaven and earth to help Kiev. The U.N. Secretary General says he's visiting Moscow as a messenger of peace after holding what he says were frank discussions with Russia. We see our future as part of European family. And the message from the mayor of Kiev to the Russian president as Vitaly Klitschko tells Euronews that Ukraine's EU membership bid is the reason behind the war. And Russia has been accused of trying to stage an alleged assassination plot against a TV journalist. We'll have the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Good to have you with us. The US and its allies have vowed to move heaven and earth to help Ukraine win its war against Russia. Representatives from 40 countries met at the Ramstein Air Base in southwestern Germany for US-led talks on bolstering Kyiv's defense capabilities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Germany's Defense Minister Christine Lambrecht pledged to provide Ukraine with 50 anti-aircraft tanks, while her US counterpart Lloyd Austin said that Washington will do everything possible to ensure that Ukraine is well-equ equipped to defeat the Russian invaders.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That visit only underscored my sense of urgency, an urgency that I know that we all share.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So I'd like this whole group today to leave with a common and transparent understanding of Ukraine's near-term security requirements because we're going to keep moving heaven and earth so that we can meet them. Meanwhile, Moldova has raised its terror threat to the highest level following explosions in the pro-Russian breakaway region of Transnistria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Moldova's President, Maya Sandu, held emergency security talks amid reports of attacks on a military unit and two radio antennae carrying Russian broadcasts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Last week, a Russian military commander revealed plans to create a corridor between southern Ukraine to Transnistria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Sandu's accused pro-Russian groups of trying to increase tensions and vow to maintain peace and stability in Moldova.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This is a complex, tense situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We are vigilant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We will take all needed measures to prevent any escalation to strengthen security of the state, to protect our citizens.

sentences.sentence: Well, to talk through all of this, I'm joined here in the studio by our correspondent, Sasha Vakulina. Sasha, in the past 24 hours in Moldova, to protect our citizens. at all times since the early 90s there around 1,500 and up to 2,000 Russian soldiers there Moscow calls that permanent peacemaking mission and they are guarding a stockpile of some 20,000 tones of munition there at the bases there now Moldova and Transnistria are not the target of what's been happening here, but it's important to understand the location of Transnistria and how is it important to the early stages of the war when Russia invaded Ukraine, trying to go to what's Odessa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01

sentences.sentence: Then they tried to do it from the sea, but then we saw with the sinking of the Moscow warship that did not that did not work also the when Moscow worship sank Moscow said did not say why what were the reasons Ukrainians said that they struck it with two missiles but in fact what happened is that Russian warships now have to stay a little bit further in the sea so this this way of taking Odessa is not really working either this is why we are seeing now that there are some forces from Transnistria that could join this fighting. Russian forces could join Russian forces in Ukraine now in the land trying to go to move towards Odessa to secure that corridor and that direct access to Transnistria. The other thing is that Moldova in fact is a rather small country. It's 2.6 million people, the population of Moldova, and it is not the member of the European Union and NATO.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So Moldova said a couple of weeks ago they couldn't even technically join sanctions because the president admitted publicly saying this would not make sense, it would not make any impact.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01

sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, as that goes on, we've got a meeting of around 40 defence ministers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01

sentences.sentence: At the same time, the way the U.S. speaks now about ukraine and providing ukraine with whatever heavy weaponry it needs this is not something we've been hearing from the beginning of this war so this is around the trust also in ukraine's capability of moving and counter-attacking and winning the war now kiev's uh statement on this is quite clear not only they say they can win that but they are very open in the list of their demands when it comes to the weaponry it's not a secret president zelensky said that the Defense Ministry said that this is a list and they passed on this list to all the countries so seeing now some of the members of NATO and some of the Allies particularly Germany being on board after the negotiating and the meeting with the American allies this is a huge change in this strategy so keep us up to date bring us up to date with the main flashpoints which we're seeing on the ground right now and I understand that Zaporizhia for the first time was actually struck.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The heavy fighting continues on all the front line in the east from Kharkiv all the way to the south. In fact, that's true, Zaporizhia this morning had two missile strikes. But it is the only city in that part of Ukraine, this is southeast of Ukraine, that has not been attacked and is not being occupied by Russian forces. Whilst up to 70% of the wider Zaporizhia region are now under Russian military control.

The UK Defence Ministry warned that Russian forces will try to attack Zaporizhzhia from the south but after weeks of preparing and somehow waiting for it the four Ukrainian forces in Zaporizhzhia got ready and prepared. They're defending themselves so this is when we saw those missile strikes today. They hit the factory in Zaporizhzhia, this is a very industrial area and there were quite a few air raid sirens today in Zaporizhzhia, this is a very industrial area, and there were quite a few air raid sirens today in Zaporizhzhia, and the population and the Ukrainian forces, they are really on high alert on what's coming now, whether Russia would try now to get Zaporizhzhia, if not by land, but then with missiles.

sentences.sentence: All right, important detailed insights there. Sasha Vakulina, as ever, good to talk to you. Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, the Secretary General of the United Nations is making his first visit to Russia since the start of the war in Ukraine. Antony Guterres is in Moscow to meet President Vladimir Putin, but ahead of that, he held talks with Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov. Guterres urged Russia to allow civilians to escape the conflict and let the UN provide humanitarian assistance. Hundreds of people remain trapped in the steel works in the southeastern port city of Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We recognize that we face a crisis within a crisis in Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Thousands of civilians are in dire need of life-saving humanitarian assistance and many of evacuation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: My proposal is for a coordinated work of the United Nations, the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Ukraine and Russian Federation forces to enable the safe evacuation of those civilians who want to live, both inside the Azovstal plan and in the city, in any direction they choose, and to deliver the humanitarian aid required.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, let's get the perspective from Russia now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

Well, that's something which is probably happening yesterday. Indeed, Sergei Lavrov said that the risk of a nuclear war over Ukraine should not be underestimated, and he called this risk real.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And the interview was broadcasted on Russian state TV just hours before the meeting with the UN Secretary General, Antonia Guterres, in Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And Antonia Guterres, at the final press conference said indeed that there were clearly two different positions on what was happening in Ukraine so it was clear that those talks were very very difficult but it we understood that Mr Guterres was trying to find some solutions to help people in ukraine so he proposed to establish this humanitarian contact group to bring together ukraine russia and the un and we have heard what he proposed um to do in mariupol and we have also heard that sergey lavrov on responded that russia opens humanitarian corridors on the daily basis we have have been hearing that from Russia actually almost every day.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So, Sergei Lavrov also blamed Ukraine for not willing to go forward with the peace talk, with the peace process, and urged to answer, to respond to Russia's proposals and said that Russia has been waiting for 10 days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And so now Mr. Guterres is supposed to meet with Vladimir Putin, but those talks, the timing is apparently postponed and hopefully it will happen tonight, later on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, Hungarian opposition leaders are in Brussels to discuss sanctions imposed on the country after Prime Minister Viktor Orban's landslide re-election earlier this month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The EU launched a never-used procedure against Hungary that could see its government stripped of EU funding.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now, the mayor of Budapest, while opposed to Orbán's leadership, wants to compromise with Brussels. He sat down with our correspondent Sándor Zsíros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Three weeks after Hungary's united opposition suffered the devastating defeat from Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, one of the faces of this movement was in Brussels. Budapest mayor Gergely Karácsonyi is lobbying against the sanctions imposed on Hungary for Orbán's controversial policies. The EU suspended recovery payments for Hungary and also announced a new rule of law mechanism that could reduce Hungary's budget with billions of euros. The mayor of Budapest wants Brussels to find a compromise with Orban.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I would not like to see Hungary having an economical and social crisis because the country was cut off from the European funds. But I also would not like to see things continuing as we saw in the past. So now I'm looking for allies in Europe and I am willing to present to the Commission and to my fellow mayors the idea to have a clear agreement based on principles between the European Union and the government of Hungary on the EU funds." Gergely Karácsony says a deal with Hungary should include finances for opposition towns like Budapest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The politician vows to keep Hungary's opposition united despite their recent defeat. But unity in itself is not enough.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It is sure that only unified opposition can win over this regime. What else do we need to do besides this unity? What do we need to do differently? What to do with the media machine of Fidesz? These are questions to answer for us in the upcoming period.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The mayor also said a new way is needed to deal with Orbán's propaganda machine, which is unique in Europe. Sándor Zsíros, Euronews, Brussels.
